reviewText:
After playing this game for a while, struggling to keep my people happy, I soon learned the trick that has allowed civilization to flourish over the past 7000 years.

If you want to keep your rich elite happy, which you will need to do if you want to make anything more complex than an agricultural economy, place your elites housing as far away from the poor as possible while ensuring they do not need to share the same services. Make sure that their taxes are low and use the bulk of public spending on disgusing the crushing poverty on the other side of town. Don't worry about the unskilled workers happiness, I am yet to find the straw that will break the camels back.

This game has provided me with a valuable life lesson in an entertaining manner - Keep the poor in their place, tip the scales towards the wealthy and everyone stays happy/ignorant.

reviewText:
The game is MUCH better than any version before. Performance is way better, and by that I mean that it doesn't laaaaag after a city gets larger or after playing for a few hours. I know this because I did beta testing and I have hundreds and hundreds of hours playing Cities XL 2012 version. That laaag the previous versions had made a lot of people give up after reaching a certain population / city size. All that is now gone.

If you played any previous version and liked it then you will love this one.

If you are a new player and want a great city builder/planner that looks great and has large maps (11x11km) then look no further.

The game by it self is fun for some time. Like any other city builder you will get bored after making a few cities. That is the case in any Sim City game as well.
BUT!
Thankfully the game has a great modding community which took this game to a whole new level.
So you will never get bored because existing mods and new ones coming out on a regular basis will keep you hooked for a long time.
There is a great comunnity forum that you just must check out:
www.xlnation.city

Don't listen to the trolls saying the game is not better, it's the same as before etc. etc.
Like I said I have hundreds of hours in previous versions and this one is extremely improved. Yes it is the same in many ways which is a good thing considering that old mods will be compatible.

- It now spreads the workload of the game across all cores of the processor which makes it run smoother when the city gets larger. Is it true multicore or not doesn't really matter as long as the performance is better, and it is.
- It now has DirectX 11 support
- They added the workshop option
- Now you can use fbx format to make mods
- They added eco green upgrades for Heavy industry and Manufacturing buildings. Upgraded buildings produce much less polution.
- It has some new transportation options (new park & ride bus system, new cargo airport)
- New leisure buildings (including a large leisure airport, speed boat marina and a yacht marina)
- New skyboxes to choose from (with clouds)
- New parks
- New polution reducing/enviroment improving buildings
- New camera (just hit 'C' on the keyboard and use page up, page down / arrow keys / Ctrl button to move around)

All in all this is a great game if you want to have FUN making/designing your dream city be it modern american style city or an older looking european city or even an asian style city. Or maybe all of those on a single map. The possibilites, specially if you use mods, are endless.

reviewText:
This is game is growing on me.. It's a mixed feeling at first because it starts out slow. I still would buy if it was released today though.

I like that the cities are large (not like Simcity), but size isn't everything.. The game needs to be fun. The cities seem to run well so far, the Steam workshop is a very nice feature and will continue to grow, some added buildings, like the bridges/road options, freeways, etc. Zooming in and seeing things in more detail is nice, clicking a car and seeing things from that cars perspective going through the city is nice. I also want to mention that there are some cool building options.. I just noticed I can place certain restaurants, a night club, etc. There are a lot of cool new buildings that you can select and place; this is in addition to the standard ones that develop in zones. These extra buildings are growing on me, and really could help make this game much more enjoyable for me.

There are tutorials in the beginning menu, and I suspect most people have not even looked at them. I am going through some of them now, and they are very nice. There also is a hidden menu on the right that shows more detailed information like traffic areas on the map, satisfaction, etc. If you hover your mouse way to the far right of the sceen the extra options come up; this is in addition the menu options of top of the screen..

As the city gets larger it becomes more of a joy to play.. I am enjoying setting up the transportation system, seeing the city expand, demand change, etc.

Things I don't like include the buildings don't develop like in Simcity which to me is a big deal (at least it was for me when I first started playing), the city progression starts out really slow (demand for goods seems to stay pretty low for a while which I think is where some people lose interest, but it gets a lot funner soon after), and the graphics/buildings aren't all that exciting to me (it is growing on me though like I mentioned in regards to the specialized buildings). Trade/manufacturing chains are to simplistic. .

I'd say if you want a large city builder this could keep you entertained, but shouldn't be the only city builder in your aresenal imo. City Skylines looks like it will be good as well, Simcity was nice from the manufacturing/trading standpoint and it was fun, but small maps. If it were me and I either liked Cities XL but wanted better performance, or you like city builders in general I'd pick this up. I will say that we also live in an 'instant gratification' world, and 1 hour of gameplay isn't going to do it for those people; so expect to see the enjoyment increase as the cities grow.

I will say I haven't developed a 'huge' city yet mostly because it starts out really slow, but I am now enjoying this game and see myself playing this more.

reviewText:
Over the past week, city building fans have waited patitently for what they were hoping to be the definitive city builder since SimCity 4. Unfortunately the opinions of players has been mixed at best. So is Cities XXL better than Cities XL or worse in every way? We have heard people say this is just a re-branding of an old game, so we decided to find out for ourselves.

Cities XL first launched in 2009 and was a spiritual successor to City Life. The game offered expansive landscapes in which to build your dream city along with online capabilities (long before SimCity). However this did not live up to expectations, the online was a flop, the game suffered from poor optimization such as only using one core on multi-core systems and various memory leaks. Despite this, fans of the series have remained loyal. Despite its faults, Cities XL has offered a very fluid and flexible city building game.

When Cities XXL was announced, it was detailed to have an all new engine, more low-level micro-management and various improvements including to performance. These alone should make it a worthy upgrade or entry point for a budding city builder.

Well the first thing we questioned is the games engine. It is possible this is a new engine under the hood, but on the surface it looks very much the same engine as before. Graphically the game looks the same, albeit with a new black UI. The controls work much the same way and the menus are largely the same. So on the surface at least, the engine seems to have been tweaked rather than fully re-worked from the ground up.

Performance wise, this game is far better. Our city of 425k inhabitants is still as smooth as when we started. In Cities XL Platinum, a similar sized city we had suffered from terrible frame rates and choppiness at this point. The UI is also more responsive than before. We did encounter some minor graphical glitches, mostly that at night, streetlights would illuminate a grid beneath them. But nothing game breaking.

There are some new buildings to place in your city, like a pollution sensor and an eco-car dealer. There are not enough with too little function to add much weight behind a new game release, but welcome additions.

Talking of pollution, this has been greatly tweaked and works more the way you would expect. It makes more sense than ever before to ensure your industry is far from residential areas, where as before it was more of a case of “Does City have Heavy Pollution? Yes, City becomes polluted everywhere quickly”.

What we found most disappointing is there is not much of the low-level micro-management that was promised. What sets the Cities XL/XXL series apart from the SimCity series is the latter focuses much more on micro management and is more organic. In SimCity you say where you want residential, commercial and industrial areas, then depending on the desirability of the area would dictate what would be built there. This would not be static, you could have a luxury hi-rise apartment, but if crime in the area goes up this may become abandoned becoming an eyesore on your landscape. Cities XL/XXL cities generally remain the same, you will not find one neighborhood going from being desirable for Elites to suddenly becoming deserted.

Despite this short coming, one major addition that will help over time to make the Cities XXL the city building game we have been waiting for is the inclusion of the Steam Workshop. I really look forward to seeing the modding community making new buildings, new functions, improvements, fixes and potentially new functionality.

If you are a fan of the series, the current 50% discount off the price is very reasonable. Even not as a full game but £15 as a kind of expansion is not bad value. If you’ve never owned a game in this series and you want large sprawling cities rather than the small towns in SimCity then this is a game well worth picking up.

reviewText: Having previously owned all of the versions since the original, I can say I was not expecting much more than an iterative update, to follow the trend of previous versions. I was however, pleasantly surprised that this improvement seems to have improved on the proccessing issues that have plaugued the game, as it seems to run a lot smoother, and the graphics seem to have had a marked improvement compared to previous releases. If you are expecting this to be a brand spanking new engine full of bells and whistles, I feel you may see this as a sore disappointment, however if, like me, you were hoping for the trend of steady improvement, that the developer has demonstrated before, along with apparently the same dedication to community created content found on sites like XLNATION, then I would hope you will be pleased with a product that does not break from tradition and only polishes what is essentially a very, by now , competent city sim, with 1000s of models, both official and custom content, to create your dream city. I also must add that in contradiction to many games nowadays on release, it DOES actually function, and is not a black hole of broken promises. It is not a game for everyone I realise, but if you like other games in the series, I cant believe you wouldnt like this one. It is not a game which holds your hand through the process, it gives back what you put in, and any person who has the interest in design, city management, or who loved ant farms as a nipper should try this out.

reviewText:
Disclaimer:  I have never played Cities XL or any other Cities game, so this is my impression as someone who is new to the franchise (not city builders though)

Rating as stands: 8/10

I have been excited about this game coming out for a while now as SimCity even after the release fixes still left most of us wanting to build a truly epic city not constrained by such a small map.  The title XXL is definitely well earned, these maps are huge!  Even the ones which have decent water coverage are still much bigger than even the all land maps of SimCity.  Cities XXL has some very similar mechanics to SimCity such as having three different types of zoning: residential, commercial, and industrial.  In this regard however it shares more in common with SimCity 4, where you customized what zones were low, medium, and high density rather than road size doing that for you (which is how the latest SimCity is).  Here you will also pick which commercial zones are for industrial, high tech, office, etc. rather than your cities population dictating such as having your factories converting to high tech jobs due to high education.  This makes it easier to plan your city and insure you have enough workers to fill your jobs.  There are four classes of residents in this game: unskilled, skilled, executive, and elites.  As you go up the affluence curve you are expected to provide more and better services.  I really enjoy the way you place the zones, you can do a simple grid but for more variety I use the free form which places small roads to make it look like a real neighborhood.  In SimCity I was always forced to make a rigid grid just to maximize space whereas here that is something I have only used for downtown since I still have tons of room to expand outward.  I also really enjoy the background music, it is well done and has pleasant melodies.  Consists mostly of relaxed indie-style and electronica (a couple songs remind me of Gramatik).  If those aren’t two genres you like I wouldn’t worry about it as the music does not overpower the game/gameplay.  Its only shortcoming is that there aren’t a ton of songs which I mention only because updates and DLC generally don’t look to add new background music so this might be it.  There are a lot of options for managing your city from trade to transportation.  It reminds me some of the options in Banished (great city builder game although it is more of a village/town builder).  I consistently found myself thinking small due to playing SimCity so much, and would micromanage a small area of maybe a few city blocks rather than pushing outward.  The maps are simply huge comparatively.

It isn’t all perfect though, one of the first things I noticed were how awkward curved roads looked.  They basically look like a lot short straight roads (think of an octagon versus a circle).  Another issue with the roads is how TEDIOUS it is to upgrade them.  It’s no better than SimCity! Worse if you consider how big the maps are and how long it will take to click on each road!  You are basically better off deleting the road, but then sometimes you cannot place a road of the same size because it keeps saying there are buildings in the way.  I also cannot for the life of me understand why they chose the color scheme for the city information UI (black text on a dark gray window?!).  I haven’t gotten to a truly massive city yet, but it is worth noting that I read Cities XL had some big problems with cities of a couple million citizens (or more) grinding your computer to a halt and crashing regardless of your hardware.  It runs very smooth for me and I have not heard of this problem occurring in this game.  Additionally, while the city certainly shows sign of life with pedestiran and vehicle traffic, there arent any of the animations you'll be used to from SimCity.  A couple times my city outgrew my police force but I never saw (or heard) any crime or saw police cars rushing around the city.  Similar for healthcare and fire services: never saw an ambulance or a fire (or even a fire truck).  Maybe my citizens are all lawful, healthy, and flame retardant?

In all if you like city builders and was disappointed in the overall lack of size of SimCity I would recommend this.  It is unfortunate that EA did publish something more like this, but this is a great example of the free market: make what the people want or someone else will.

reviewText:
The last thing I'll be able to understand is the negative reviews. Because of how poorly optimized the last Cities games were, people began developing some sort of bias that any future Cities game will always be bad. That's not the case here, anymore.

Cities XXL is actually a big improvement from Cities XL 2012.

I remember getting CXL12 back in 2013, and that was sort of my replacement for the awful SimCity game. Originally, I thought it was pretty cool. I made over 20 cities in a span of 5 months, but that's not the point. The game was no longer stable by the time my city was as big as a quarter of the map, and that's not good, of course. After a year-long hiatus from the game, I've wanted to play it again, but it's not even playable anymore. The game would randomly crash every 15 minutes or so, and that was very bothersome, and the game couldn't go above 30 fps, and it basically became a slideshow. CXL12 was ruined for me.

But that was when I realized that I could get CXXL for a 50% discount. I've looked on their website and it says that they've improved their engine, which would make the game run faster. Being a customer of Focus for over 10 years, I knew they wouldn't lie to me, so on the day my father gave me a $50 Steam gift card, that was the first thing I bought with it.

I began playing the game now and wow, they really weren't lying. There was definitely some improvements to the game's engine. Of course it still goes crazy after about 10 million residents, but remember, this engine is based off of a 2005 game engine that can only use one core, which is pretty impressive if that's true. My game was able to stay at a stable 60 fps even with a million residents, and so far, no crashes yet!

This proves once again that a terrible video game franchise CAN become good if problems are fixed. I recommend this game to anyone.

1) So far im well past population where issues start occuring in the old version and I have flawless performance. So the folks on here and youtube that are stating there is no performance increase I'm calling BS.

Do I think they are shady and does it anger me that I had to pay 20 bucks for a patch? Yes

reviewText:
Don't be scared of the poor reviews this game is getting...

It seems that every single negative review is from people who are familiar with the Cities series who believe this is the exact same game as it's predecessor.

Every single positive review is from first timers to the series, who all seem to enjoy it quite a bit.

As a brand-new, first time Cities player, I am loving this game! I find myself much more immersed in this game than I am in any recent version of Sim City. The framerate chugs a bit when laying roads or residential zones, and the overlays for power, water, waste, and fuel could use a little work, but overall this is a big city builder/manager that is a lot of fun!

Compared to the most recent Sim City (and all Sim City's for that matter), there seems to be less focus on things like utilities, police, fire, health, and education, but a much larger focus on managing unemployment rates and happiness levels. Happiness is affected by unemployment rates, utilities, police, fire, health, and education, so I guess it all comes together in the end. It's obvious that the primary purpose of the game is to grow as big as possible, and keep everybody content while doing it. Not a bad thing. I find myself wanting and trying and succeeding in getting bigger, before I am forced to try and catch up with my citizens by building luxury buildings to give them something to do, upgrading/rebuilding roads to handle the increase in volume, and trading with an NPC AI to help cover my shortcomings.

And I'm having a blast doing it!

Based on the size of the map when I zoom out completely, my city of 150,000 people, with a land area similar to that of an entire Sim City plot, is maybe a little less than one-fifth of the total area I can build upon. And I'm pretty spread out. For those who like to build one massive city, welcome home.

If you are new to the series, I highly recommend this game. I understand why all of you fans of the Cities series are so upset. But for someone with no expectations, it seems to be well worth the time.

reviewText:
EDIT: Definitely get Cities Skylines instead of this. Skylines is 100 times better and even has water physics and everything. However if you insist on getting a Cities XL game then XXL is the one to get.

Coming from Cities XL 2012 to this, gameplay wise, its almost exactly the same game.
Its got the same UI, just recoloured from blue to black (although it does look a little more tidy).
Resources are still all the same as well as all the categories of buildings such as heavy industry.

I have noticed a few new features and buildings in the game such as being able to edit how many plots the game places in the square building zones when building and choosing if the game places plots on one side or both sides of the road with the linear zoning tool. New buildings include things like the pollution sensors and electric car dealership just to name a few.
Now whether these new features and buildings were in Cities XL Platinum, I have no idea. I never played Platinum or have seen any gameplay of it.

The graphics look slightly better in this than Cities XL 2012 but its really not by much. I'm not sure if its me but the colours look a bit more vibrant in XXL though.

Performance is much better in this than XL 2012. Focus Interactive have finally figured out that multicore computers are a real thing. In Cities XL 2012 there would be a noticeable drop in performance once your city hit around 50k population and would gradually get even worse as the population grew. In Cities XXL however, I have a city with 600k people and although there is a bit of a loss in perfomance it is no way near as bad as XL 2012 and still perfectly playable.

For a new player to the Cities XL/XXL this game would probably be an 8.5/10. For a player who has owned previous Cities XL games its a 5/10 at best.
So basically if you're new to the Cities XL/XXL franchise. Get this.
If you've owned previous Cities XL games and are willing to pay for some really minor new features and multicore support then get this but maybe wait for a sale.
If the performance of previous Cities XL games doesn't bother you then don't get this

I'm gonna vote yes to this game simply because of the fact that you can now build massive cities and still get a playable frame rate which in previous titles was almost impossible.

TL;DR
The performance is a lot better. The are some very minor new features. Other than that its pretty much the same as previous Cities XL games.

reviewText:
For starters if you own Cities XL 2012 then you may find this game a bit expensive compared to what you will be gaining for the upgrade. It runs smoother than previous versions and does not sufer from the horrible memory leaks found in prior titles. I find the new UI to be a step in the wronge direction. Much of the text is hard to read because the colors are so close (black text on a grey background for example.) It does take up slightly less screen space so those with smaller monitors may find that a plus.

As far as what is new:
- The new freight airport is a nice addition.
- Also found in the marinas is a few new leisure options to make the waterways more usefull.
- In the view panel you have the option to set a different background option and is nice for screenshots.
- Some of the roadways are available from the start without turning on expert mode. This helps early game traffic managment and city planning.

The main reason i recomend this title is for the people who have not played this title before and are looking for alternatives to games like SimCity. This title has the feel of SimCity 4 but with greatly improved graphics and trade options done on very large maps. It does however have it's own bugs and oddities though most are just anoying in this version and not game breaking. The steam workshop support allows for easy mod access. If you are new to the series watch some youtube video's and tutorials first (as mentioned before Cities Xl 2012 videos are still valid with only minor changes.) This game is not like other city building games and you will want to get used to the diferences.

reviewText:
I've not played the previous Cities games but I am a fan of city building simulations such as Sim City. There's a lot of talk of this game being the same as the one previous, but as I haven't played those I can only judge it on what it is as an individual game.

The maps are big, very big compared to Sim City, but then most maps on most games are bigger than those.

The cities seem to run smoothly with no lag for me, but I have only had low density cities of around 100,000 people.

It doesn't seem to go as indepth as Sim City though with regards to pollution, crime, health and other factors. However I feel that this game is more about building the largest rather than building the most perfect city.

I have had trouble with loading up saved games and there has been some difficulty in placing roads but I feel that overall it's a fairly decent city building simulator if you haven't had a previous Cities game.

In short, it's worth a purchase if you like city sims.

reviewText:
I'm new to the series, but I absolutely love the game. It's deep, fun, and a bit demanding of time. I play on and off line, and I could see myself lost in this for hours on end. Replayability is super high, as you'll learn from your mistakes and want to start over, or at least that's how I feel. My advice when you start is to not skimp on roads!!! I don't regret my purchase. And I am Very Satisfied.

reviewText:
It is Cities XL. Those expecting an entirely new game will be disappointed. With that said, the game does indeed have multi-core support, and runs very smooth. It has full Steam integration, with Workshop support. It does have some new content, though much of the game is the same. Clouds, and other little features are sprinkled around the game.

Basically, everything that they said was going to be added, was. It's worth the $40.00 bucks if you haven't played it before, as it is the prettiest city building game around by far. Its worth $20.00 as an upgrade, because multi-core does indeed work, and works well.

Anyone hating on the game, saying nothing was added is wrong. By default, the mere fact that multi-core was added makes their statement wrong, as that is not something that is just easily tacked on. As it stands now, a lot of the bigger mods, such as RHM aren't compatible, but is already starting to be converted over. Is XXL perfect? No. Is it an improvement over Platinum? Yes, a big one. Is it better than unmodded Simcity 4 or the new abomination? Yes.

reviewText:
So, after the first hour I am able to write a first, short review.

Let me show a few good things about cities xxl.

+ If you played Cities XL and you liked the game, you will most certanly like Cities XXL. Its nearly the same.

+ New maps and new music. But the music is also a negative part, but we will get to this later.

+ I already have a pretty big city and didn't experience fps drops so far.

And now the negative parts:

- The music. Really, am I the only one who thinks that this music is absolutely depressing? Its a sad, female voice most of the time, it gives you the feeling you are doing something terrible, like killing a family with a shovel or something. I accept the typical citybuilding - chillout music, but this? Okay, its only my taste.

- A few graphic glitches, like flickering streets in building mode and stuff like that. Nothing they coulnd't fix in a few small patches.

- As I mentioned in the positive part - this game is very similar to Cities XL. Very, VERY similar. Imagine Cities XL with a black interface and thats it.

- Wrong messages. At something around 2.500 Citizens you get the achivement you unlocked the medium buildings for the workers and the supply stuff, like electricity. Wrong message, because this happens at 5.000 citizens.

After the first small game I can say: This game is definitly not 'new' its basically Cities XL with a new Interface. If you like City building games you can buy it, if they fix the small bugs I mentioned above.

And please, developers, give us some happy music. Make it dubstep if you have to, but not this depressing stuff which makes the game hard because you cant see ♥♥♥♥ thorugh your manly tears.

reviewText: More of the same. It's better than SimCity and doesn't suffer from *most* of the previous games' performance issues. If you like city building games it's worth picking up on sale. It's still better than SimCity though since I can have a functional city larger than the size of a single neighborhood. I recommend the game if it's on sale, if it's not, you wouldn't be missing much by picking up the older versions.

reviewText:
Ok... This game has gotten a lot of bad press from some very angry people, but I have to say... I LOVE THIS GAME!!!
The positives:
- The graphic are great!
- Things are running smoothly on my machine
- I like driving through my city and standing on top of buildings looking at what I've done
- The farms are expansive
- It's really fun seeing all the different buildings
- It's challenging trying to balance the city needs, especially trying to solve traffic issues
- I love that services are distance-based and not radial, and they have decent coverage
- There are so many things to do and new things unlocking all the time
- The tutorials help a LOT
- I haven't encountered a single bug.

The negatives:
- The MUSIC... omg
- It's lacking some flexibility with the roads (tight angles, on/off ramps... maybe I just haven't gotten that far)
- I don't like having to bulldoze long stretches of roads to make minor tweaks and to upgrade roads.
- It's more difficult than I thought to master the mechanics.
- The look around" feature with the mouse wheel is WAY too sensitive. It's an art form to pan where you want.
- I wish I could choose whether or not to have suspension beams on my high-traffic viaducts.
- It's kind of a pain having to drill down into each tool (and having it reset the default tool)

The neutrals:
- The controls are fine once you know how to use them
date:
although some people are REALLY passionate about this.
- The UI is intuitive and clean in my opinion. I used the tutorial so I know where everything is.

Overall
recommended: I REALLY like this game so far

reviewText:
If you are a New to Cities Series Games, Read everything. It will give you some insight about the Thumbs down.

If you are an avid Cities XL player Skip this first part.

New to Cities? This game is for you. Stop reading the thumbs down reviews. they really aren't helpful….period. If you're looking at it, it's most likely because you are looking for a more original city building simulation game. Its simple mechanics allow you to focus more on the city building while easily managing economic efficiency.

Once you spend the first 30 minutes going thru the tutorial *i recommend* your basicly ready to lay out something quickly and effectively. Starting is very simple and allows you to focus on the design and layout. While later slowly introducing elements that open up more economic strategy. City utilities are managed on a simpler and more macro size scale. You can create trade routes between two cities to share resources, *yet to explore it more* and so on.

Basicly its enjoyable.

Now for quality. This game has no more bugs than an average AAA title does that releases for “your console of choice” or any other system. I personally have not run into anything. I have a 2014 edition of the razer “blade pro” playing on full settings at 3k. I have not experienced any lag or slowdown. I average about 60 fps and dips down to about 45 fps while exploring on ground level. So im sure anyone with a mid core gaming desktop or consumer laptop should be able to run this ok. I have also managed to run it on low settings on a surface pro 3 i5 variant. Runs around 20fps, so hopefully that gives you a benchmark range of what to expect.

Well what's with all Bad hype behind Cities XXL?

Lets be real, what more do you want to see from this particular series? A future space theme skinned game that really gets no improvement in gameplay and just adds more bugs?

If you are familiar with the Cities XL game and really enjoyed it for what it was, then you will like Cities XXL. Not a lot of re learning so we can focus more on what we love to do. Build huge gigantic cities! I dont have the biggest city yet *only been playing for about 3 hours on 5x speed* but so far iv not run into many hitches.

Cities XXL is basicly the same thing as Simcity: Cities of tomorrow was. But less disappointing.


To be fair in their advertising “at least from what i saw” never said it was going to be a new engine. And all the screenshots look like they might have been taken from Cities XL. So what did you expect when buying itt? I feel the game undertook some massive improvements as far as rendering, and speed. I treated this buy more like an expansion then a whole new game. Yes it does suck they did not just improve the old engine but.

I mean we got multiple truck simulators, farm simulators, bus sim…..you get the idea. Only so much can be done with a game series that is so fragile right now no one wants screw anything up.

They added steam workshop content to the game and which is like the developers giving us the tools to build whatever you want. So for the hardcore citie player you have nothing to complain about. If we give it a chance to grow it has the chance to become basically whatever we want.

No online multiplayer, And honestly this should really be no surprise. Games like Anno and Simcity do not have the best track record of been successful at multiplayer online. Why risk breaking a perfectly playable game with multiplayer. We can still share cities with our friends.

Steam workshop. Must i say more?

In short i got exactly what i wanted. Hoping that the community will grasp it and love it for what i believe it deserves.

7/10 would buy again. I really want the creationist user to grasp modding this game. While i'm not looking for anything in particular it would be cool to see what people come up with.

reviewText:
{Owner of Previous City XL Titles}
All things considered this is a pretty decent game, considering the city building genre has traditionally been a limited market. The new additions were merely evolutionary and cosmetic and thats ok; more of a DLC than a new experience. Worth the $20 pre order in my case.

GOOD - Cleaner Interface, new building filter meu, atmospheric back drops (skies), environmental enhancements simply provide a generic improvement to areas around them (new parks, ?sensors?, etc.), a new freight airport, new cruise ship port, and soundtrack.

BAD - Persistent bugs - roundabouts and highway interfaces fail to visualize traffic flow (cars disappear), will take awhile before moddings translate from previous titles (if you find alot of use from modding it may be wise to wait a bit), core fan requests still not available (i.e. missing intercity/above ground rail infrastructure)

BOTTOM LINE: If you enjoy city building games then the game is worth its weight. Is it perfect? No. The game excels in such a way that its shortcomings are glaring; hence the frustrations lobbed its way. Whether Focus Home Interactive should/could do more will fall to the sea of opinions. Decide for you. And while I certainly fall in the camp that asks more of FHI, I still find enjoyment in the title's current state; the Black Swan that it is. What can I say . . . I like city building.

reviewText:
Ignore the trolls and haters.

The game runs great.  UI improvements are a welcome addition.  It's a shame trolls are spamming negative reviews.  I suspect most haven't even played the game.  If you own any previous titles, we're only talking $20.  That's the cost of some DLC's.  There's easily more than enough content to justify the $20 purchase.

Cities XXL is a relaxing experience.  You plop down zones, draw roads, and watch your city grow.  You can spend your time balancing out the different zones and create a self-sufficient city, or you can trade for tokens in order to satisfy that demand.

I've logged close to 250 hours in this series.  I'd highly recommend it to any fan of city-building games.

reviewText:
For those who already know and enjoy the franchise, Cities XXL is a must,  the 50% discount is a fair deal for Cities XL owners. The multi-core support is the most important feature of this release along with Steam Workshop integration for custom content.

If you never played Cities XL, this could become your favourite city builder.


The new UI though is not very different, looks better than the old one, at least it looks more stylish for today standards.  The new filter allows you to filter buildings by Architectural style, period, geographic location, etc. That's quite useful considering the game has tons of buildings and many more are constatly created by the modding community.

The game overall feels and looks the same but the improvements are noticeable, the new skybox that allows you to select different environments (cloudy days, beautiful sunsets, etc) makes the cities look more alive and realistic.  The shadows were improved and the texture filtering is better (no blurry textures).

There are some new buildings like freight airport, a new sport marina, bike rental, and many more including new transport related buildings like Park and Ride. Industries now can be upgraded to more eco-friendly versions.  There are no new residential buildings, though.

The game's still not perfect, but still quiet enjoyable and no other game offers the graphic detail or the map sizes of CXXL.

If you didn't like the previous versions, move along. It's likely you ain't gonna like this one either.

reviewText: Just a few minutes into the game and improvements from the prior versions are evident.  Having purchased this for 50% off, I cannot complain about the price.  I enjoy sandbox simulation games and though I loved SimCity, this is the next level.  Mind you, these are merely my initial impressions based on only 30 minutes or so of gameplay.

reviewText:
Game was fun 4 years ago and it still is. But it's the f*cking same game all over again. They should be embarrassed promoting this as a new game especially since they hear all the complaining every time they release this game under a new name. Are they just laughing at us or do they really think they made a new game?

If you already own this game under a former name, you should not buy this one again. If you haven't played it before, go for it because it is a good game and it's fun to play. The maps are the same size as Cities XL but they already were huge back then.

Nevertheless I give this game a thumbs down, because of Focus' lies as they seem to enjoy this behavior. Shame on you once again!

reviewText:
7 out of 10 on its own, 2 out of 10 for a sequel.    - Still better than Sim City
=====================
* A patch came out. It seems to have helped a little bit, but it's still not exactly butter smooth.

*The game is a resource hog, but you'll be able to power through it with a quad core. Graphics requirements are mild.

* It does seem to have some lags when you're changing your zoom and going through different tools because its pulling textures and file from my HDD on the fly - something many games get away with these days.

*The upgrades" not enough to get me back in after the last ones
date: though some new tools and tweaks make life a little easier. For someone brand new to this franchise
recommended: you'll probably love the scale. I know I did with these games. I've always thought of them as more of a sandbox than a challenge in management. They do make mechanics and cause - effect simulations pretty easy to figure out
hoursPlayed: so you can learn it pretty fast."

reviewText: Well, I use to have a positive review, but after months of waiting after release, this review is now negitive because not only did the developers fail its old community, I feel it has failed its new one.\nLiterally almost zero developement been done in those months, no indepth micromanaging, traffic is impossible to work with as you can't do special turnpikes,make straightaways, the tunnels are horrible, can't do anything special with the roads what so ever, no content being added (even though it was released as a finished" game) has left the game with no veriety
date: and since there was such a huge let down between XL and XXL the modding community is almost non-exsistent leaving us a game worse than the most recent simcity.\nThe only thing this game might have over other games is larger maps but whats the point of larger maps if the game just lacks
recommended: or just sucks in general. Keep your money

reviewText: Interesting and fun game. Basically it’s a city builder. You place “zones” rather than specific buildings. The populace will start to create and fill your city based on your zone. I haven’t played too many city building games so I won’t be able to compare it to much. I enjoy it a lot.
